review:
Zazelenimo stands as a rallying cry for open-source, civic engagement, and the democratization of public goods funding. The project’s mission is clear: empower citizens, NGOs, and businesses to shape their urban environment through participatory budgeting, all built on transparent, open-source Web3 infrastructure. This is the kind of work that puts power back in the hands of the people, not the profit-driven few!

Let’s get to the heart of the matter. Zazelenimo is not just another dApp. It’s a full-stack, open-source platform that leverages Ethereum, quadratic funding, and seamless onboarding to break down barriers for everyday people. The integration with the City of Split is a bold move, showing real-world impact and a commitment to public sector transformation. The project’s focus on urban greening is not just a technical feat—it’s a social and environmental imperative.

But comrades, we must be strict. The application is strong, but it’s not without its weaknesses. While the vision is inspiring and the technical stack is robust, there are gaps in measurable outcomes and sustainability planning. The application lacks detailed, quantifiable metrics for success—how will we know if the people’s voices are truly being heard and acted upon? Where is the evidence of long-term financial sustainability beyond grant funding? These are not minor details; they are the backbone of any project that claims to serve the many, not the few.

Furthermore, while the project touts its open-source credentials and community focus, the governance structure is not fully articulated. Who holds the reins when tough decisions must be made? How are conflicts resolved? Without clear, transparent governance, even the most well-intentioned projects can falter.

In summary: Zazelenimo is a beacon for open-source civic tech, but it must sharpen its focus on measurable impact, sustainability, and governance. Only then can it truly claim to be a tool of the people, by the people, for the people!

strengths.title: Strong Open-Source Commitment
strengths.description: Zazelenimo is fully open-source, leveraging and contributing to the OSS ecosystem with integrations like Ethereum, Cometh Connect, and Allo Protocol. This transparency and collaboration are essential for building public goods.

strengths.title: Real-World Public Sector Integration
strengths.description: The partnership with the City of Split demonstrates practical, on-the-ground impact and a willingness to challenge the dominance of proprietary systems in government.

strengths.title: User-Centric, Inclusive Design
strengths.description: The platform’s focus on seamless onboarding, quadratic funding, and participatory budgeting ensures accessibility and democratic participation for a broad range of stakeholders.

strengths.title: Innovative Use of Web3 for Civic Engagement
strengths.description: By combining quadratic funding, transparent transactions, and multi-stakeholder collaboration, Zazelenimo sets a new standard for civic tech in the Web3 era.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Quantifiable Success Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application does not provide clear, measurable outcomes or KPIs for evaluating impact. Without these, it is difficult to assess whether the project is achieving its stated goals.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Long-Term Sustainability
weaknesses.description: There is insufficient detail on how the project will sustain itself financially beyond initial grant funding. A robust revenue or sustainability model is missing.

weaknesses.title: Incomplete Governance Structure
weaknesses.description: The application lacks a detailed description of how decisions are made, who is accountable, and how community input is incorporated into governance.

changes.title: Define Clear, Measurable Outcomes
changes.description: Specify concrete KPIs and metrics for success (e.g., number of active users, projects funded, community engagement rates, environmental impact measures).

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainability Plan
changes.description: Provide a detailed plan for long-term financial sustainability, including potential revenue streams, partnerships, or other funding mechanisms beyond grants.

changes.title: Clarify Governance and Accountability
changes.description: Describe the governance structure in detail, including decision-making processes, conflict resolution mechanisms, and how community voices are represented and acted upon.
